title: 3D Spectral-Element Method Simulations of Ultrasonic Wave Propagation in the Bottlenose Dolphin Head
author: Carlos García A. (Dipartimento di Geoscienze, Università degli Studi di Padova), Vladimiro Boselli (CNR-IREA), Aida Hejazi Nooghabi (Universität Hamburg), Andrea Colombi (ZHAW Zürich University of Applied Sciences), Lapo Boschi (Dipartimento di Geoscienze, Università degli Studi di Padova)
relevance_why: The paper explores wave propagation in complex biological structures, which has potential applications in audio signal processing and bioacoustics, relevant to audio generation and manipulation tasks.
background: Simulating how ultrasonic waves propagate through the intricate anatomy of a dolphin to understand its echolocation capabilities.
contribution: This study introduces a hexahedral mesh built from Computed Tomography (CT) data to accurately simulate wave propagation in a bottlenose dolphin head, enhancing understanding of marine mammal acoustic biology.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous models struggled with high-frequency simulations due to computational limitations and linear-system inversions in traditional methods.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work employs the Spectral-Element Method (SEM), which provides exponential convergence and efficient parallel computing capabilities, allowing for more accurate real-time simulations.

key_innovation: Utilizes advanced hexahedral meshing techniques from CT data to create accurate anatomical models for ultrasonic wave simulations without the constraints of traditional finite-element methods.
real_world_impact: The findings may advance bioacoustics research, informing conservation efforts and enhancing our understanding of navigation in marine environments, which is crucial for biodiversity preservation.
limitations: The model is simplified, omitting the complexity of certain anatomical features like teeth and air sacs.

new_terms.Spectral-Element Method (SEM): **Spectral-Element Method (SEM)** is a numerical technique that applies high-order polynomial basis functions to achieve high accuracy in simulations, particularly for wave propagation in complex geometries.
new_terms.Computed Tomography (CT): **Computed Tomography (CT)** is a medical imaging technique that combines X-ray images taken from different angles to produce cross-sectional views of specific areas of a scanned object.
